model.name: WRONG - TEST - IGNORE Amsterdam
model.description: It’s easy to fall in love with the fantasy of L.A. Nowhere else—from the newly revitalized downtown to the postcard-perfect beaches of Malibu—has such sunny skies, such insistent glamour. But for all its glossy appeal, this is also a town with substance: an excellent food scene, like the vegan Mexican at Gracias Madre; superior shopping at mainstream retail meccas like The Grove and L.A. institutions [Fred Segal](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/los-angeles/fred-segal) and Maxfield; and sweeping views of the city from atop Runyon Canyon…all of which combine to make a legendary place even more so.
model.seoName: Things to Do in Los Angeles: The Conde Nast Traveler Guide
model.seoDescription: Traveling to Los Angeles? Conde Nast Traveler's guide to Los Angeles, California provides the only information you need to know about where to stay, eat, and play.
model.socialName: Condé Nast Traveler"s Guide to Los Angeles: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play
model.socialDescription: The best of LA, from fresh to classic, compiled by Conde Nast Traveler editors.
model.dontMiss:
### EAT

[#restaurant: /restaurants/5493cd30dd5fe6503a0d9646]|||
The team behind Gjelina recently opened [Gjusta](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/venice/gjusta)—a bakery in Venice a few blocks away.
|||

### STAY

[#hotel: /hotels/5493d07044d4f45926eafb57]|||A new boutique hotel opens in Silverlake at the end of January, above Bar Covell called, naturally, [Hotel Covell.](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/los-angeles/hotel-covell)|||

### SHOP

[#shop: /shops/5493d204dd5fe6503a0d9649]|||Detroit-based watchmaker [Shinola](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/los-angeles/shinola) also is making a home in Silver Lake. Opened last month, it'll join the block's other retail outposts of [Aesop](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/venice/aesop) and APC.|||

### PLAY

[#activity: /activities/547f474d15fa044b14f3b31e]|||Don't miss the exhibit, Andy Warhol: Shadows, at [MOCA,](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/los-angeles/museum-of-contemporary-art-los-angeles) on view until February 2.|||

fields.name: Laura Dannen Redman
fields.shortBio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of *Condé Nast Traveler*. When she was three, her dad alleges she sat up in the back seat of the family station wagon, struggling against the seat belt to look out the window, and said, "I want to see the world!" Some things never change. She has a decade of international newspaper and magazine experience; most recently, she was deputy editor of *Time Out Singapore* and arts editor of *Seattle Met* magazine, where she won a National City and Regional Magazine Award (CRMA) for Multiplatform Storytelling. Laura is a Princeton grad with a master’s in journalism from Boston University’s College of Communication.

fields.name: John Wogan
fields.shortBio: John Wogan is a senior editor at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Senior Editor John Wogan has covered culture, food and travel news for *Conde Nast Traveler* since joining the magazine in 2012, and co-edits the annual Hot List. He previously worked at *Travel and Leisure* and *Town and Country.*

featuredEats.name: W Lounge

address.street: Plaça de la Rosa dels Vents 1

featuredEats.description: This lounge is in the W Hotel, built at the edge of the Mediterranean. It has a marine design and resident DJs spin deep house music tracks, until the wee hours, on a set that looks like a jet ski on the shimmering water.

featuredEats.name: El Xampanyet
featuredEats.description: This beloved tapas restaurant has been serving up its own brand of cava called “Xampanyet” (pronounced champanyet: an allusion to “champagne”) since 1929, along with artisanal draft beer and simple tapas of anchovies (among the city’s best), cheese, and local charcuterie. Join the locals crowding around the high marble tables in the front section– it’s the best spot to take in the lively atmosphere.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Tapas bar with its own champagne brand.

featuredEats.name: Bikini
featuredEats.description: It's one of Barcelona's oldest clubs, started as an open-air terrace bar and mini-golf in 1953, but their mix of touring live groups and some of the city's best DJs at work, assures a young, lively crowd. It houses four "spaces" that are around a central meeting point: a space for dancing to salsa, another for house and hip-hop, a third by reservation with private tables for bottle service or cocktails, and a metropolitan-style cocktail bar.

featuredEats.name: Otto Zutz
featuredEats.description: Located in a 19th-century textile factory, this classic club—opened in 1985—has eight bars and three floors for dancing and drinking, and is a perennial favorite of locals. While the style of music has changed from rock and disco to hip-hop and house over the years, the party vibe has not and it's still a place folks go to have a real night out. The club gets going after midnight and winds down from 5 am.

stay.body:
## The dollar may be taking a beating in Europe, but you don't have to. Our correspondents have combed five favorite European cities for the best small, stylish, and reasonably priced accommodations (most are $250 a night or less) and restaurants that serve great food at a great value. From a Roman villa on the Tiber to a sleek modern hotel just off Las Ramblasall you have to do is choose.
[#image: /photos/53ea919e976f8f2d44d57288]||||||[]()

**BARCELONA**

**Hotels**



 Most of the 28 rooms in **Hotel 54 Barceloneta,** the newest hostelry in the increasingly trendy fishing quarter, have fantastic views of Port Vell, and all have Wi-Fi. The decor is light and airy, with playful touches like neon mood lighting and bathrooms with green-glass sinks. **Strengths:** Near the beach; sunny rooms; a cushioned rooftop chill-out zone that gives the place an Ibiza vibe. **Weaknesses:** Noise from the hip basement nightclub drifts up to the lower rooms (34-9-32-25-00-54; [hotel54barceloneta.com](http://www.hotel54barceloneta.com/); doubles, $194–$241).

The 45-room industrial-style **Hotel Onix Liceo,** just off Las Ramblas, has a well-lit lounge area with a fireplace, and a large terrace with a floral mural. Rooms are chic and modern, done in a black, gray, and chocolate-brown palette. There's no bar or restaurant, but the hotel serves a hearty buffet breakfast for an extra $13. **Strengths:** Comfortable furnishings; high-speed Internet access. **Weaknesses:** Rooms facing the street can be noisy, especially on weekends (34-9-33-03-41-54; [hotelsonix.com](http://www.hotelsonix.com/); doubles, $141–$176).

[#image: /photos/53ea91a0976f8f2d44d572aa]||||||The courtyard of Palazzo Odoni[#image: /photos/53ea91a0dd4d6a0b75efb227]||||||Palazzo Odoni's formal lobby[#image: /photos/53ea919e976f8f2d44d57278]||||||Hotel Locanda San Barnaba[#image: /photos/53ea919edd4d6a0b75efb207]||||||Osteria Anice Stellato[#image: /photos/53ea91a1dd4d6a0b75efb239]||||||Villa Laetitia's main entrance[#image: /photos/53ea919e976f8f2d44d57298]||||||Hôtel La Manufacture[#image: /photos/53ea91a1dd4d6a0b75efb24b]||||||The Hoxton's lobby[#image: /photos/53ea919edd4d6a0b75efb217]||||||B&B Belgravia

Situated on the busy Gran Via, the elegant **Hotel Soho** is a ten-minute walk from the Plaça Catalunya. By local architect Alfredo Arribas, the minimalist look features designer frills such as Verner Panton lamps, supercomfortable beds, and natty glassed-in bathrooms. The best rooms are on the seventh floor and come with wood-decked terraces. There's no restaurant, but breakfast is served in the lobby and room service is available until 9 p.m. A snazzy business center in the basement and a cool rooftop plunge pool make the place a bargain. **Strengths:** Excellent location; great style. **Weaknesses:** Heavy traffic on the Gran Via means rooms on the lower floors can be noisy (34-9-35-52-96-10; [nnhotels.com](http://nnhotels.com/); doubles, $148–$404).

The **Market Hotel & Restaurant** has large rooms with polished wood floors, Oriental lacquered furniture, and black-tiled bathrooms. Some have terraces; all have Wi-Fi. In a quiet, leafy neighborhood a 15-minute walk from the city center, it's good for those seeking peace rather than action. Downstairs is a sophisticated restaurant. **Strengths:** Quiet and stylish. **Weaknesses:** Interior rooms are dark; elevators are reserved for disabled guests (34-9-33-25-12-05; [markethotel.com.es](http://markethotel.com.es/); doubles, $129; two-bedroom apartments, $172–$229).

**Apartments**



 All nine **Boria BCN** lofts and suites are multilevel and measure at least 484 square feet. They have small but fully equipped kitchens and a decor featuring cappuccino tones and hardwood floors (some have two bedrooms). **Strengths:** Great for families; concierge service in the lobby from 8 a.m. to 11 p.m. **Weaknesses:** Storage space is limited; you don't get your own key for the main building (34-9-32-95-58-93; [boriabcn.com](http://boriabcn.com/); lofts and suites, $241–$362).

**Staying Cool** combines the luxe of a trendy small hotel (bathrobes, fluffy white towels, fancy toiletries) and the independence of an apartment. Located in the arty neighborhood of El Raval, this one-bedroom is a tasteful blend of original features and modern style: Huguet tiles and bow beams in the living room and bedroom; poured concrete in the kitchen and bathroom. **Strengths:** The apartment comes with Wi-Fi, DVD player, iPod speakers, and a fridge stocked with juicing oranges. **Weaknesses:** Shabby entrance; no elevator (44-1618-32-4060; [stayingcool.com](http://stayingcool.com/); $218–$278 per night, with a two-night minimum).

The creation of an ex–art curator and graphic designer, **Destination BCN** rents out artfully decorated apartments. The best values are the sleek designer lofts near the Plaça Universitat ($195–$269) and the quieter hideaways off the beaten path in Poble Sec ($155). **Strengths:** All have fully equipped kitchens and multimedia bells and whistles. **Weaknesses:** Traffic noise in the apartments on the Plaça Universitat (34-6-87-91-45-66; [destinationbcn.com](http://destinationbcn.com/); apartments, $155–$350 per night, with a four-night minimum).

**Dining**



 **Taller de Tapas** packs in local workers with its excellent-value lunches. By night, the ancient stone walls buzz with the chatter of the lively crowd who come to savor regional specialties such as _pimientos de padrén_ (green peppers that occasionally pack a fiery punch) and Spanish soul food like rib-sticking callos, or tripe stew (28 Calle Comtal; 34-9-34-81-62-33; tapas, $4–$16). **Inopia,** a brightly lit neighborhood bar co-owned by Albert Adria (pastry chef at the legendary El Bulli), specializes in traditional tapas featuring top-notch ingredients, including local anchovies and gooey sheep's cheese. Most of the patrons stand, but there's a sit-down area for those who book in advance. Evenings only (104 Calle Tamarit; 34-9-34-24-52-31; tapas, $3–$15). Rising star chef Josep Nicolau presides over **Rosal 34,** hidden in seldom-visited Poble Sec. The menu has a seasonal repertoire of dishes such as steamed cockles with passion fruit and razor clams with vanilla and lime oil (34 Calle Roser; 34-9-33-24-90-46; tapas, $5–$24).



 –Tara Stevens

[]()

**LONDON**

**Hotels**



 Behind its traditional Georgian facade, **B&B Belgravia** is a sleek oasis of contemporary calm: white walls, walnut floors, funky furniture, and unexpectedly luxurious bedrooms. Room rates include free Internet access, cappuccino (from a proper espresso machine), breakfast, and magazines. **Strengths:** Chic and homey surroundings; laid-back but helpful staff. **Weaknesses:** No air-conditioning (44-20-7259-8570; [bb-belgravia.com](http://bb-belgravia.com/); doubles, $223).

The 205 rooms at **The Hoxton** are smart and compact, with Frette linens and duck-down duvets, flat-screen TVs, power showers, and Pears soap. The price for a double—which is cheaper the earlier you book—can be as low as $2 a night with occasional promotional offers but is typically about $200. Included are a light breakfast delivered to your door, mineral water, fresh milk for hot drinks, and Internet access. To boost your chances of landing a $2 room, get on the hotel's mailing list. **Strengths:** A superior central location; loads of free amenities. **Weaknesses:** The same rooms are sold at a variety of prices, depending on how far in advance you book (44-20-7550-1000; [hoxtonhotels.com](http://hoxtonhotels.com/); doubles, $2–$296).

A cozy town house hotel in Marylebone, **Montagu Place** has 16 rooms in three categories, defined largely by the size of the bed. Only "Comfy" rooms on special offer fall into the budget category, but that's no hardship: Accommodations include a pleasing ensemble of pastel colors, Molton Brown toiletries, free Internet access, and CD and DVD rentals and players. **Strengths:** A luxurious retreat in a prime location. **Weaknesses:** Breakfast is not included in the room rate (44-20-7467-2777; [montagu-place.co.uk](http://montagu-place.co.uk/); doubles, $296–$369).

**Twenty Nevern Square** is a newly restored redbrick Victorian town house. All 20 guest rooms have an old-fashioned feel, complete with silk curtains and hand-carved wooden beds. **Strengths:** Close to Earl's Court station. **Weaknesses:** The cheapest rooms are tiny (44-20-7565-9555; [twentynevernsquare.co.uk](http://twentynevernsquare.co.uk/); doubles, $200–$350).

**Apartments**



 **45a Cloth Fair** is a basic but functional Georgian apartment steeped in history. The two-bedroom flat, which sleeps four, overlooks the ancient Church of St. Bartholomew the Great and features period architectural details and antiques as well as a thoroughly modern kitchen and bathroom. Book through the Landmark Trust. **Strengths:** Close to Smithfield Market, the Museum of London, and St. Paul's Cathedral. **Weaknesses:** No Internet access or TV; a rock-hard living room sofa (44-1628-825-925; [landmarktrust.org.uk](http://www.landmarktrust.org.uk/); $380 per night, with a seven-night minimum).

**Citadines Trafalgar Square** offers 187 apartments in the heart of London, ranging from studios that sleep a couple to two-bedroom flats. **Strengths:** The apartments are within walking distance of London's most famous monuments, galleries, and theaters; comfortable furnishings; no minimum stay required. **Weaknesses:** Mid-'80s hotel chain–style living room decor doesn't impress (44-20-7766-3700; [citadines.com](http://citadines.com/); studios, $220–$248).

Those staying in London for a week or more may prefer the comfort of a new purpose-built block like the **Courtyard, Wimbledon.** Located on a tree-lined street, it's a five-minute walk from the main train station, with easy connections to South Kensington and Waterloo stations (the trip into central London takes approximately 15 minutes). The flats have one or two bedrooms (extra beds are available) as well as balconies, satellite TV, washing machines, and dishwashers. **Strengths:** Spacious, comfortable, modern, and light-filled. **Weaknesses:** Located outside central London (44-20-8944-1444; [apartmentservice.com](http://apartmentservice.com/); one bedrooms, $210 per night, with a seven-night minimum).

**Dining**



 Gordon Ramsay's latest venture, **The Narrow** occupies an exquisite spot on the river in Limehouse, where it serves up traditional British dishes at reasonable prices. A white onion and wild garlic soup with croutons, for example, is $7; soft herring roe on toast, $9 (44 Narrow St.; 44-20-7592-7950; entrées, $16–$25). One of the best Vietnamese restaurants in London, the canteen-style **Viet Hoa** is cheap and cheerful, attracting the trendy Shoreditch crowd (70-72 Kingsland Rd.; 44-20-7729-8293; entrées, $8–$18). **Afghan Kitchen** is a small eatery with a limited menu but superb, wholesome food: The Afghan chicken, chickpea curry, and fried baby eggplant are all delicious, as are the yogurt-based drinks (35 Islington Green; 44-20-7359-8019; entrées, $10–$13). The authentic South Indian food at rock-bottom prices makes the trip to **Saravana Bhavan,** in Zone 3, worth it. A simple _masala dosa_—a huge rice pancake filled with spiced potatoes and accompanied by four different chutneys—is just $5 (300 High St. N.; 44-20-8552-4677; entrées, $3–$12).



 –Rosemary Behan

[]()

**PARIS**

**Hotels**



 In the thirteenth arrondissement, the _Hôtel La Manufacture_ combines a nineteenth-century facade with a hip interior. Rooms are small and spotless, and cost from $147 a night for a standard double to $263 for room 74, which has a view of the Eiffel Tower. Book online for reduced rates. **Strengths:** Family-friendly; warm, English-speaking staff; stylish rooms. **Weaknesses:** Away from the city center; small rooms; breakfast is unimpressive and not included in the rate (33-1-45-35-45-25; [hotel-la-manufacture.com](http://hotel-la-manufacture.com/)).

The **Hôtel Chopin,** tucked down a passageway off the Grands Boulevards metro stop, has become a synonym for the well-priced _hôtel de charme._ Rooms are cheerful and very French. **Strengths:** Quiet; central location; good for families, couples, or singles. **Weaknesses:** Least expensive rooms are dark; views are uninspiring—except for the top floor, which looks over the rooftops (33-1-47-70-58-10; [hotelbretonnerie.com](http://hotelbretonnerie.com/); doubles, $109–$124).

In the fashionable Marais, the Christian Lacroix–designed **Hôtel du Petit Moulin** resonates with a different kind of Frenchness, and has an unostentatious facade hiding idiosyncratic rooms. The two-person "Comfort Room" goes for $240 a night year-round, while superior and executive rooms, normally $333 to $372 a night, can be as low as $242 on Sunday nights—although there is a two-night minimum. **Strengths:** Central location; chic decor; trendy bar; wheelchair friendly. **Weaknesses:** Snooty receptionists; overpriced breakfast; a charge for Wi-Fi (33-1-42-74-10-10; [paris-hotel-petitmoulin.com](http://paris-hotel-petitmoulin.com/); doubles, $243–$472).

The **Hôtel Esmeralda,** in the Latin Quarter, is small and scruffy, but what it lacks in polish it makes up for in bohemian charm (floral wallpaper, flea market furniture). Bare-bones singles with no shower are as low as $47 per night, while doubles with a private shower and overlooking Notre-Dame are between $108 and $128. **Strengths:** Great location; friendly staff. **Weaknesses:** Shoe box–size rooms; a tad dusty; no elevator or TV (33-1-43-54-19-20; no Web site).

**Apartments**



 **Lodgis,** a Paris rentals agency, has more than 1,000 furnished apartments, with prices starting at about $36 a night for a studio. **Strengths:** Consistently good-quality apartments; well situated; reasonable prices; an authentic Paris base. **Weaknesses:** Staff are lax about replying to e-mail and phone queries; be prepared to clean the apartment and do laundry at the end of your stay or else pay a supplement (33-1-70-39-11-11; [lodgis.com](http://lodgis.com/)).

**Chez Vous** offers apartments in Paris's most exclusive areas. One-bedroom apartments—such as Bisou, in the Latin Quarter, and Mimosa, beside the Place des Vosges—are $260 a night and sleep up to four (two in daybeds). Traveling en masse makes things cheaper still, and Chez Vous's two-bedroom apartments—including Picasso, in an ancient _hôtel particulier_ in the heart of the Marais—comfortably sleep six for $440 per night and up. **Strengths:** Welcome service upon arrival (with English-speaking staff); linens and towels provided; attractive apartments in central areas. **Weaknesses:** Smaller apartments are typically dark; layout can be awkward—especially in those with sleeping lofts; antique decor means the flats are not suitable for families with young children (415-331-2535 in California; [chezvous.com](http://chezvous.com/); rates vary widely depending on the apartment; most have five-night minimums).

The two-bedroom **Rue des Écoles,** on the border of the fifth and sixth arrondissements, is bright, roomy, and kitted out with a fabulous kitchen. **Strengths:** Great location; charming building with high ceilings; washer, dryer, and dishwasher; free overseas calls and Internet access. **Weaknesses:** Very basic decor and few amenities (781-383-6006 in Massachusetts; [panacherental.com](http://panacherental.com/); $450 per night, with a five-night minimum).

**Dining**



 Places worth crossing the city for are numerous, but **Chez Gladines,** a Basque restaurant in the Quartier Butte-aux-Cailles, sees more pilgrims than most, with Parisians lining up nightly (no reservations) for copious $9 salads, wine from $16 a bottle, $4 chocolate mousse, and the charmingly manic staff. Step aside when you hear "_Chaud! Chaud! Chaud!_"—this will be a waiter delivering sizzling snails to hungry diners (30 rue des Cinq Diamants; 33-1-45-80-70-10; entrées, $11–$16). The small, no-frills **Kaza Maza,** set beside the Panthéon, in the fifth arrondissement, is a local favorite, serving delicate tabbouleh, lemon-grilled chicken, moussaka, and Lebanese pastries to eat in or take away (1 rue de l'École Polytechnique; 33-1-46-33-96-74; entrées, $4–$13). For more traditional fare, **Bistro Victoire** is a fine choice. A zinc bar, cheery staff, and an enticing menu of entrées (all $12) and desserts and cheeses (all $7) combine to make this a convivial stop in an otherwise expensive **quartier** (6 rue de la Vrillière; 33-1-42-61-43-78).



 –Tara Mulholland

[]()

**ROME**

**Hotels**



 In the trendy Monti district, the 27-room **Duca d'Alba** is close to the Colosseum and the Forum and only a few steps from the subway and the No. 117 electric bus, which stops at many sites in the historic city center. All of the rooms are elegant, and those on the fourth floor, though smaller, come with little terraces. **Strengths:** An excellent location; friendly, generous service. **Weaknesses:** Small rooms; no outdoor public space (39-06-48-4471; [hotelducadalba.com](http://hotelducadalba.com/); doubles, $147).

Near the delightful Villa Torlonia park and museum complex, the recently spruced up **Villa del Parco** is a quiet, sunny refuge from the tourist hordes and is well connected by bus and subway to Rome's historic squares and monuments. The brighter rooms are on the second floor, and the mansard quarters on the fourth are small but charming (the other floors have not yet been renovated). **Strengths:** Lovely garden for breakfast or an aperitif. **Weaknesses:** Not within walking distance of the heart of the city (39-06-4423-7773; [hotelvilladelparco.it](http://www.hotelvilladelparco.it/); doubles, $170).

The family-run **Il Gattopardo Relais,** on the piano nobile of an elegant nineteenth-century building close to the Vatican Museums and the subway to Piazza di Spagna, has six nicely decorated rooms. Each has first-class amenities, including air-conditioning, a minifridge, a bar, and Wi-Fi. **Strengths:** The 24-hour reception desk is efficient and hospitable; rooms are stocked with everything you might need, from a toothbrush to slippers. **Weaknesses:** If you're not an early riser, noise from the front hall can be disturbing (39-06-3735-8480; [ilgattopardorelais.it](http://ilgattopardorelais.it/); doubles, $189–$256).

Anna Fendi (of the fashion dynasty) and her daughters opened the stylish **Villa Laetitia** hotel along the Tiber in an Art Nouveau mansion with meandering gardens. Every room and bath is unique and decorated with antique tiles that Fendi collected on her travels and other eclectic objets d'art. For a splurge, consider a lavish suite. A spa is slated to open this fall. **Strengths:** Well-equipped kitchenettes; beautiful details. **Weaknesses:** Hard-to-find staff; breakfast not included (39-06-322-6776; [villalaetitia.com](http://villalaetitia.com/); doubles, $202–$270).

**Apartments**



 **Il Colosseo,** a studio with a kitchen, has a small terrace with a big view of the Colosseum. It's impeccably furnished and comes with a flat-screen satellite TV, Wi-Fi, and even a cell phone. **Strengths:** A fridge stocked for breakfast; a complimentary bottle of wine. **Weaknesses:** Short on space for a long stay (39-06-4890-3612; listing number 229 on [romanreference.com](http://romanreference.com/); $120 per night, with a three-night minimum).

The **Piazza di Spagna** penthouse has a sprawling terrace with views of a leafy street near the famous square. There's one comfortable bedroom, a bathroom, a full kitchen, and a spacious living/dining area with a convertible couch that's big enough for two. The helpful English-speaking owner is just downstairs, and the Eternal City is at your feet. **Strengths:** Fabulous location; terrace to party on. **Weaknesses:** Entrance is through the vestibule of the owner's apartment (Gabriella Morici, owner, 39-338-396-5266; [enroma.com](http://www.enroma.com/), in Spanish; $200 for two per night, $245 for four, with a two-night minimum).

In a seventeenth-century building on a quiet street along the Tiber, near the Piazza Navona, **Tor di Nona** is coolly elegant, with plush white couches and wood-beam ceilings. The second bedroom has two double beds, and there's a small terrace and courtyard. Amenities include air-conditioning, Internet access, a CD player, a washing machine, and an espresso maker. **Strengths:** Well appointed, bright, and quiet. **Weaknesses:** No elevator, but it's only one flight up (39-06-9932-0047; [rentalinrome.com](http://rentalinrome.com/); $255–$340 per night, with a three-night minimum; $241–$317, with a seven-night minimum).

**Dining**



 A three-minute walk from the Vatican Museums, **Osteria dell'Angelo** is quintessentially Roman, with marble-topped tables, butcher-paper place mats, and brusque but friendly service. A four-course dinner includes a pleasant wine produced at the owner's vineyards. Dine outdoors in good weather (24 Via G. Bettolo; 39-06-372-9470; prix fixe, $34). Tradition reigns at **Trattoria Monti,** a family-run eatery near the Basilica of St. Mary Major. The small dining room packs in Romans who come for winning dishes such as the tortello pasta—one oversized but delicately stuffed raviolo made with fresh egg yolk (13a Via San Vito; 39-06-446-6573; entrées, $20). **Palatium,** a sleek wine bar between the Piazza di Spagna and the Via del Corso shopping mecca, has a full menu of local specialties, featuring pecorino and ricotta cheeses, fava beans, and Gaeta olives. Lunch and dinner are always lively (94 Via Frattina; 39-06-6920-2132; entrées, $19–$27).



 –Mimi Murphy

[]()

**VENICE**

**Hotels**



 In a sixteenth-century building with eighteenth-century frescoes and an outdoor patio where breakfast is served along a serene canal, the 13-room **Hotel Locanda San Barnaba** is almost perfect. The property has been in Silvia Okolicsanyi's family for more than a century, and she runs the place with the care of someone who is banking on having it for another hundred years. Avoid the two ground-floor rooms, and pay $14 more for a superior double with a frescoed ceiling. **Strengths:** Impeccable service; simple yet classic furnishings; perfect location near the Church of St. Barnabas. **Weaknesses:** Dial-up Internet (39-041-241-1233; [romanticasrl.191.it](http://www.romanticasrl.191.it/); doubles, $190–$200).

The ten rooms in the fifteenth-century **Palazzo Odoni Suites and Rooms** offer a serenity that will make it difficult to leave—as will the homemade sweets for breakfast. **Strengths:** Spacious, romantically decorated rooms; rooftop views; broadband Internet; luxe, recently redone bathrooms. **Weaknesses:** Almost no common areas—you're either in your room or out roaming the canals (39-041-275-9454; [palazzoodoni.com](http://palazzoodoni.com/); doubles, $162–$190). Breakfast is served in your room every morning at the homey yet luxurious **Ca'della Corte.** The 12 accommodations have an eighteenth-century flair and excellent modern bathrooms; many are big enough for a family of four. **Strengths:** A pleasant courtyard perfect for rambunctious kids. **Weaknesses:** No Internet, although Wi-Fi is said to be arriving soon (39-041-715-877; [cadellacorte.com](http://cadellacorte.com/); doubles, $225).

The terrace outside room 4 at the **Pensione La Calcina** overlooks the large Giudecca Canal all the way to Palladio's masterpiece, the Church of the Redeemer—but any room with a canal view won't disappoint. Some rooms have Wi-Fi, and there is a guest computer with Internet in the reception area. With its large windows and comfortable couches and chairs, the lobby recalls Venice at the end of the eighteenth century, before the fall of the republic. Breakfast is served on a wooden deck that juts over the canal. **Strengths:** Simply yet tastefully decorated rooms; elegant common areas. **Weaknesses:** Side rooms get very little natural light (39-041-520-6466; [lacalcina.com](http://www.lacalcina.com/); doubles, $150–$220).

**Apartments**



 Located in the splendid Fondamenta della Misericordia residential neighborhood, **2579 Cannaregio** is all about its terraces. The rooftop terrace—with jasmine, wisteria, and a pomegranate tree—has a panoramic city view and is ideal for an unforgettable cocktail party or dinner. The apartment itself is small, and you'll be sleeping on a (comfortable) pullout couch. **Strengths:** Fantastic views; daily maid service. **Weaknesses:** Tiny bathroom (brucelei@unive.it; $214 per night, with a seven-night minimum).

The spacious two-bedroom apartment at **290 Guidecca,** on Guidecca Island, has a modern kitchen and comfortable furnishings. It overlooks the Giudecca Canal, and the view extends into the heart of the city. **Strengths:** Roomy; great views. **Weaknesses:** Cramped shower; slightly out of the way but a five-minute vaporetto ride from the center of town (39-348-873-6815; luisgu@tin.it; $216 per night, with a three-night minimum).

The beautiful private garden at **3099 Cannaregio** affords the peace and quiet so often necessary after a few hours on the busy byways of Venice. This recently remodeled apartment sleeps up to four—on a pullout queen-size bed and a pullout full-size bed. **Strengths:** Modern bathroom; big open kitchen; very quiet. **Weaknesses:** A 20- to 30-minute walk to the Piazza San Marco (39-041-718-931; $270 per night).

**Dining**



 Locals like to say that if a restaurant doesn't require reservations, it probably isn't worth eating at, which is why you'll have to book ahead for a table at **Osteria da Rioba** (insist on one outside). The place oozes Venice, with canalside seating and local specialties such as numerous preparations of cod with polenta and fresh squid-ink pasta. The only drawback: the loud live music that emanates from a nearby bar (2533 Cannaregio; 39-041-524-4379; entrées, $14–$47). Everything is simple at **Osteria Anice Stellato,** from the wooden tables to the fresh fish that's always cooked just right. Again, opt for a table along the canal (3272 Cannaregio; 39-041-720-744; entrées, $11–$47). Dropping in to **Osteria Al Ponte** for an informal meal with the locals is as close as you can get to being a Venetian. Order the cod and other cicheti (small dishes)—the daily pasta plate is often subpar (6378 Cannaregio; 39-041-528-6157; entrées, $8–$36).



 –Eric Sylvers
stay.hed: 50 Affordable Gems in Europe's Most Expensive Cities
stay.seoTitle: 50 Affordable Gems in Europe's Most Expensive Cities
stay.socialTitle: 50 Affordable Gems in Europe's Most Expensive Cities

fields.name: CNTraveler.com
fields.shortBio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.

stay.body:
Hotels around the world have invented many creative ways to welcome guests and bid them adieu:









[#image: /photos/53d9c4a5dcd5888e1459b420]||||||

To welcome returning guests (and and certain others), **[Esperanza](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/mexico/esperanza-cabo-san-lucas-cabo-san-lucas-mexico )** in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, offers freshly prepared guacamole and salsas, accompanied by a margarita made with fresh juices; these are followed by a 15-minute, mini head-and-neck massage.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a5dcd5888e1459b410]||||||

Upon arrival in their room, VIP guests at the **[InterContinental Park Lane](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/europe/united-kingdom/intercontinental-london-park-lane-london-england)** in London receive butter shortbread, made in Scotland from a traditional recipe and natural ingredients. To wash it down, they also get a bespoke Earl Grey blue flower tea called Wellington Tea, named after the Wellington Arch, which the hotel overlooks.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a56dec627b149d0c8b]||||||

All guests at the **[QT Gold Coast](http://www.qtgoldcoast.com.au/)** in Australia will find a designer lemon juicer, swizzle stick and high-end glasswear in their room when they open the door; they can then call room service for lemons and ice, and use the kit to make freshly squeezed lemonade.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a56dec627b149d0c9b]||||||

**[Twin Farms](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/twin-farms-barnard-barnard-vermont)** in South Royalton Vermont, stocks its rooms with a wood puzzle of a local scene. The puzzles—which vary by season and are hand-made by nearby Stave Puzzles—become collector’s items for repeat visitors.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a56dec627b149d0c9d]||||||

Inspired by its Catalan-themed restaurant, Mercat a la Planxa, the [**Blackstone Renaissance**](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/renaissance-blackstone-chicago-hotel-chicago-illinois ) in Chicago puts freshly popped, Spanish-style, buttered popcorn—seasoned with Spanish paprika, smoked cheddar powder, and cumin—in the rooms of VIP guests.






####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a8dcd5888e1459b454]||||||

Special and VIP guests at the **[Ritz-Carlton, Palm Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/ritz-carlton-palm-beach-palm-beach-florida)** are welcomed with a presentation of a juicy whole orange, orange salad, marmalade, brioche toast, and spiced pecans. Food is also the way sister hotel **[Ritz-Carlton, South Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/ritz-carlton-south-beach-miami-florida)** says hello: a homemade chocolate dessert, featuring an artwork, is placed on a dish designed by Morris Lapidus, architect of the 1953 hotel. Guest are also gifted with a coffee table book, which they can keep, on the hotel’s art collection.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a7dcd5888e1459b432]||||||

The **[Capella Ixtapa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/mexico/capella-ixtapa-ixtapa-mexico)** in Mexico gives all visitors straw hats and totes to use on the beach or around the resort—and you can take them home as souvenirs when you leave.






####  






**[Hotel Arts](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/europe/spain/hotel-arts-barcelona-barcelona-spain)** in Barcelona presents all guests a small bottle of extra virgin olive oil, produced in Catalonia from the first cold pressing of arbequina olives, as a farewell gift.


####  




[#image: /photos/53d9c4a7dcd5888e1459b434]||||||

Expect to hear singing when you leave the **[Ka’anapali Beach Hotel](http://www.kbhmaui.com/cms/view.aspx/Show/Home )** in Maui. That's because employees gather in the lobby, recite an original lei chant, and hand out kukui-nut leis—all signifying your adoption into the hotel’s extended _ohana_ or family. When guests return, they are encouraged to bring their leis back and exchange a darker-color kukui nut on the original with a lighter-colored nut, to honor the passage of time and preserve of a Hawaiian tradition.



 



 


##### More amenities:


[The Hotties: Best Perks, Extras and Amenities at 18 Hot List Hotels](http://www.cntraveler.com/hot-list/2012/hotels/best-new-hotel-amenities-perks-extras-hot-list-2012)



[The Gold Standard](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/best-hotel-amenities-gold-standard.html)



 [Hotel Amenities: More than Pringles and Cans of Coke](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/03/hotel-mini-bars-amenities-fridge-snacks-drinks.html)



 [For Earth Day We Give You: Green Hotel Amenities](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/04/sustainable-green-eco-friendly-hotel-amenities)



[First Class Travel: What's Inside Airline Amenity Kits](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/02/first-class-flight-amenity-kits-american-airlines-united-virgin.html)

stay.body: [#image: /photos/53db1ceb6dec627b14a1a408]||||||< br>If you'd prefer an apartment to a hotel, you can find one through Spain vacation-rental specialist Mary Vaira of El Sol Villas. The red arrow points to an apartment she represents in Barcelona's Gaudi-designed < ahref="http://www.elsolvillas.com/prop/apartment-townhouse/barcelona/pedrera-1/717#">La Pedrera building.  < br>< br>A question has come in from reader Ira Kaplan:< br>< blockquote>"Having trouble finding the right travel agent for a family trip to Barcelona in fall 2010, and I'm hoping you can point me in the right direction. We are four adults - A mother and father in their 70s and a brother and sister in their late-40s/early 50s - looking to spend around 6 nights in Barcelona. This is a bit harder to book than your typical trip because three of us are leaving from Minneapolis and one from NYC; we want to also hit Amsterdam for 2 nights, either on the way to or from Barcelona; and we ideally are looking for an apartment (although two hotel rooms would do). What we don't want are any kind of tours (we like doing our own thing) or ultra-expensive, lap-of-luxury accommodations. It seems we fall into that great middle between a trip that we can book by ourselves and those complex, tour-filled trips I see being pushed on so many travel agent websites. I've e-mailed a couple of travel agents and gotten either an unsatisfactory or no response, and I'm wondering where to turn. Hoping you can help."< div>< blockquote>< blockquote>< br>< div>< div>If I were you, I'd book the airline tickets and Amsterdam hotel on your own and then book the Barcelona portion of your trip either through a < ahref="/travel-tips/travel-specialists/2009/08/126-Top-Travel-Specialists">Spain specialist who knows the hotels well and negotiates special rates -- have you tried Virginia Irurita of < ahref="http://madeforspain.com/">Made for Spain? I've booked two separate, affordable hotel stays in Barcelona through her -- or via a Spain < ahref="/travel-tips/rentals/2009/06/The-2009-Villa-Agent-Rolodex">vacation-rental specialist such as Mary Vaira of < ahref="http://www.elsolvillas.com/">El Sol Villas, who does have a few Barcelona apartments in her portfolio.< br>< br>< div>Any other readers have ideas? If so, please share them in the Comments section below.< ahref="http://perrinpost.truth.travel/media/images/lp_Pedrera_Apartment_Barcelona_091020.jpg">< br>
stay.hed: The Best Way to Book 6 Nights in Barcelona
stay.seoTitle: The Best Way to Book 6 Nights in Barcelona
stay.socialTitle: The Best Way to Book 6 Nights in Barcelona

fields.name: Wendy Perrin
fields.bio: Wendy is the founder and editor of [WendyPerrin.com](http://www.wendyperrin.com/).  She is also TripAdvisor’s first-ever Travel Advocate, sharing her advice with TripAdvisor’s visitors.  Formerly, as *Condé Nast Traveler*’s Director of Consumer News and Digital Community, Wendy wrote the magazine’s travel advice column The Perrin Report for 17 years, The Perrin Post blog for eight years, and The Perrin Postcard newsletter for four years. She started out long ago as the magazine’s Ombudsman, investigating reader complaints about travel companies and helping wronged travelers get compensation, and that led to her book *Wendy Perrin’s Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know* (Fodor’s).

contributorsAuthor.name: Laura Dannen Redman
contributorsAuthor.shortBio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of Condé Nast Traveler.
contributorsAuthor.bio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of *Condé Nast Traveler*. When she was three, her dad alleges she sat up in the back seat of the family station wagon, struggling against the seat belt to look out the window, and said, "I want to see the world!" Some things never change. She has a decade of international newspaper and magazine experience; most recently, she was deputy editor of *Time Out Singapore* and arts editor of *Seattle Met* magazine, where she won a National City and Regional Magazine Award (CRMA) for Multiplatform Storytelling. Laura is a Princeton grad with a master’s in journalism from Boston University’s College of Communication.

contributorsAuthor.name: John Wogan
contributorsAuthor.shortBio: John Wogan is a senior editor at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
contributorsAuthor.bio: Senior Editor John Wogan has covered culture, food and travel news for *Conde Nast Traveler* since joining the magazine in 2012, and co-edits the annual Hot List. He previously worked at *Travel and Leisure* and *Town and Country.*

featuredStays.name: Hotel 1898
featuredStays.description: Steps from the Plaza Cataluña, "right on the Ramblas," this property used to be the headquarters of the Philippines Tobacco Company—the initials of the company remain engraved on its revolving entry door. "Spacious rooms" done in colonial style are equipped with marble baths and a pillow menu. Spend an evening nibbling on home-made tapas and sipping cocktails at the "amazing rooftop terrace and bar" or sampling Spanish wine at Vinoteca H1898. In a former cellar,"the spa and pool area are the best in the city"—the spa has a heated pool, therapeutic fountains, and massages inspired by the Silk Road.

featuredStays.name: Hotel Casa Fuster
featuredStays.description: Near Sagrada Família, "in the heart of the arts district," this hotel is named for a Mallorcan society gentleman who purchased the building for his wife in the early 1900s. Built during the Modernisme architectural movement of the late 1800s (the Catalan version of Art Nouveau), it is characterized by curves and a white marble facade. "Some rooms are better than others," so opt for a deluxe, which has a king-size bed and faces the Passeig de Gràcia. Sip tea or a cocktail at Café Vienés, or dine on Mediterranean at Galaxó. The rooftop pool and terrace offer views across the city.

featuredStays.name: Hotel Mercer, Barcelona
featuredStays.description: One block in from the old Roman walls, a refined retreat in the heart of the Gothic Quarter.
featuredStays.shortDescription: A rarefied retreat in the Gothic Quarter.

featuredStays.name: Mandarin Oriental, Barcelona
featuredStays.description: The location of this former bank headquarters, which opened as a hotel at the end of 2009 on "the lovely Passeig de Gràcia," ensures that "guests can easily stroll to restaurants and shopping." The "very contemporary and modern room design" by Spaniard Patricia Urquiola mixes leather and velvet upholstery with a palette of green, black, and gold. Relax in a Scandinavian-style armchair and dine on authentic Catalan cuisine at Moments restaurant, or visit Banker’s Bar to sip cocktails in a venue reminiscent of a gentlemen’s club.

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53d9d41f6dec627b149d9466]|||The "Guacadog" from The Dog is Hot in Barcelona|||

In a country celebrated for its _jamón_ and suckling pig, the idea of eating vegetarian seems almost outrageous. And yet, vegetarian culture is on the rise in Barcelona. I grew up macrobiotic and, along with my [Context Travel](http://www.cntraveler.com/contributors/context-travel) colleague in Barcelona, Lily Heise, still maintain a vegetarian lifestyle. On a recent night out together we were astounded at the growing list of vegetarian options, from the uber-casual to the gourmet. Here are our top five veggie spots in the city.










##### La Bascula


Tucked away in the medieval alleyways of El Born lies **1** this surprisingly spacious café. Cooperative-run La Bascula uses all organic ingredients in its fresh juices, hearty meals (Lily and I loved the seitan), and homemade desserts. It’s also committed to sustainable dining–even the plates and utensils are bio-degradable. Community tables (made from repurposed doors) give a casual and friendly ambiance. Ironically, the restaurant occupies a former candy factory. _Carrer del Flassaders, 30 bis_










##### [Vegetalia](http://www.restaurantvegetalia.com/)


**2** [Vegetalia](http://www.restaurantvegetalia.com/) is a calm respite in the heart of the bustling Barrio Gòtic. Try the smoked tofu tempura and vegetable paella, or for something quicker opt for a freshly made smoothie on the terrace. The restaurant uses organic ingredients where possible, including some grown in its own private garden. Great for lunch, Vegetalia is not to be confused with its neighbor a few doors down, Gopal, which serves veggie fare of the fast-food (and sub-par) variety. _Carrer dels Escudellers, 54_










##### [Teresa Carles](http://www.teresacarles.com/)


Our favorite, **3** [Teresa Carles](http://www.teresacarles.com/), founded in 1979, has just the type of sophisticated vegetarian cuisine one might find in New York. Indeed, with its clean and chic interior (exposed brick and natural wood tables) it’s easy to forget we’re on a narrow street just off La Rambla. The restaurant has an extensive menu of meat-, dairy-, and gluten-free options that would please even the most intense carnivores. We particularly loved the homemade burger; and we weren't the only ones—the lunch line was out the door. We can’t wait to go back for dinner. _Carrer de Jovellanos, 2_










##### Sesamo


**4** Sesamo is a charming and well-reviewed restaurant offering modern vegetarian cuisine. Owner and head chef Alfredo, originally from Argentina, has been living in Barcelona for more than a decade. Not surprisingly, his creations are inspired by culinary traditions from around the world. The restaurant is intimate with an extremely friendly staff: Alfredo is known for coming out to chat and happily accommodates vegan clients. The tasting menu is a must, as are reservations at dinner. _Carrer Sant Antoni Abat, 52_










##### [The Dog is Hot](http://www.thedogishot.com/)


Though by no means a fully vegetarian restaurant, **5** [this cool hot dog joint](http://www.thedogishot.com/) offers the choice of a meat or tofu dog and is a fun possibility for vegetarians on the go, especially those traveling with carnivorous companions. Select from a multitude of pre-designed combinations–we liked the “Guaca Dog” with guacamole, cheese and onion. A word from the wise: Be prepared to get messy; toppings are shoveled on and there are not proper tables._ Carrer Joaquin Costa, 47_









[#iframe:https://www.google.com/maps/ms?msa=0&msid=216498248091250582578.0004d4e86958109d4212b&ie=UTF8&t=m&ll=41.382605,2.173276&spn=0.016358,0.021758&z=15&output=embed](508x508)||| |||



 View [A Guide to Vegetarian Restaurants in Barcelona](https://www.google.com/maps/ms?msa=0&msid=216498248091250582578.0004d4e86958109d4212b&ie=UTF8&t=m&ll=41.382605,2.173276&spn=0.016358,0.021758&z=15&source=embed) in a larger map





 Photographby Sara McCarty

fields.name: Sara McCarty, Context Travel
fields.shortBio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel.
fields.bio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel. Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together  local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.

eat.dek: After closing El Bulli, Albert and Ferran Adrià opened Barcelona restaurant Tickets. To give you a taste of what you could be eating tonight, Chef Albert shares the secrets behind some of the tapas dishes.
eat.hed: What's for Dinner at Albert and Ferran Adrià's Tickets

items.title: El Bosque Animado
items.caption:
"Mushrooms made with a yuzu meringue, green pistachio 'sponges' prepared in a microwave, lemon yogurt, yuzu, bits of chocolate, wild strawberries, and coconut sorbet.




Desserts are very important at the restaurant. In this case we made fun of ourselves, with an infantile adaptation of one of the desserts on the menu at El Bulli, which we originally created for our book _Nature." _

items.title: Las Navajas a la Parrilla
items.caption:
"The clams are washed, sealed in a vacuum, and cooked for four to six minutes depending on their thickness. They are then placed in ice water, opened, the stomach is removed and they are sliced in to small bite-sized bits. They are then grilled and seasoned with a sauce made of very finely chopped garlic and ginger, white wine, and olive oil. As soon as the sauce begins to boil, they are removed from the heat and finished with a touch of lemon and a little chili.




Once again, we were inspired by traditional flavors with our own personal touch while rediscovering ingredients, like ginger, used in traditional Catalan cooking.




The cuisine at Tickets is straight-forward and inspired at its roots by traditional Spanish cooking; even if the techniques are modern, they are always at the service of the ingredient, and the ingredients are about pure basic flavors that are familiar.




Perhaps what surprises our guests the most is the intensity and purity of the flavors. It’s something we work very hard at."

items.title: Mollete
items.caption:
"This is a steamed bread that we make at Tickets, stuffed with a mixture of pancetta and pig’s jowls cooked at a low temperature until it’s very sweet. At the moment when the bread is ready, it is stuffed with pieces of buffalo mozzarella, the pancetta, the pig’s jowls, and a little mustard, and then it is grilled.




It is an adaptation of a traditional Andalucian recipe, _los molletes, _which consists of a white bread filled with various stuffings."

items.title: Huevos 1.40
items.caption:
"The quail’s eggs are cooked for 1 minute and 40 seconds so that the yolk remains raw. They are then submerged in oil and covered in bread crumbs that have been mixed in an _almogrote_ sauce that is typical of the Canary Islands and includes oil, vinegar, garlic, ñora peppers, cumin, salt, and cheese.




The adaptation of these traditional techniques, like the bread crumbs and the _almogrote_ sauce, lets us give a new 'shell' to the egg."

items.title: Miniairbag
items.caption:
"Pizza dough is cut into five-centimeter circles and baked until puffy and crunchy. Then a small hole is made and the dough is filled with a mousse of Manchego cheese and it’s then covered with a layer of the same cheese and a layer of wood-oven-roasted hazelnuts, caviar made from hazelnut oil, and lemon thyme.







The dish evokes, in an entertaining and contemporary way, the traditional flavors of a Manchego cheese toast. The flavors of hazelnut and thyme are flavors that can also be found in certain cheeses."

items.title: Las Olivas
items.caption:
"This dish is prepared by submerging the juice of olives in a water bath and with an algae called alginate. The combinaton of the algae with the calcium in the olive juice leads to a reaction in which the juice becomes a soft sphere. The technique is adapted from an industrial process and was first tried at El Bulli in 2001. Once the sphere has been made, it’s marinated with garlic that has been sautéed till lightly brown, thyme, rosemary, and lemon and orange peel.







What’s surprising is the texture. The flavor and the preparation are totally natural. It recalls marinated olives."




 




**Read other "What's for Dinner" interviews:


**




[What's For Dinner…At the Oscars' Governors Ball?](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/02/Wolfgang-Puck)




[What's for Dinner at Chicago's Alinea](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2011/11/world-menu-alinea-in-chicago)




[What's for Dinner at…Dinner by Heston Blumenthal](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2011/11/Whats-for-Dinner-at-Londons-Dinner-by-Heston-Blumenthal)




[What's for Dinner at... Menton in Boston](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/03/whats-for-dinner-boston-restaurant-menton)




[What's for Dinner at Singapore's Restaurant André](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2011/11/Whats-for-Dinner-Andre)

items.title: Popular Galleries
items.caption:
*** [7 Perfect Days in 7 Popular Ports](http://www.cntraveler.com/cruises/2012/03/photos-european-cruises-mykonos-st-petersburg-rome-spain-turkey-monte-carlo-slovenia.html)

eat.seoTitle: What's for Dinner at Albert and Ferran Adrià's Tickets
eat.socialDescription: After closing El Bulli, Albert and Ferran Adrià opened Barcelona restaurant Tickets. To give you a taste of what you could be eating tonight, Chef Albert shares the secrets behind some of the tapas dishes.
eat.socialTitle: What's for Dinner at Albert and Ferran Adrià's Tickets

fields.caption:
"Mushrooms made with a yuzu meringue, green pistachio 'sponges' prepared in a microwave, lemon yogurt, yuzu, bits of chocolate, wild strawberries, and coconut sorbet.




Desserts are very important at the restaurant. In this case we made fun of ourselves, with an infantile adaptation of one of the desserts on the menu at El Bulli, which we originally created for our book _Nature." _
fields.title: El Bosque Animado

eat.hed: The One Drink to Have in Barcelona
eat.dek: You can’t leave Barcelona without trying this traditional beverage. Plus: how to order, how to pay, and local etiquette tips.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/54170afa17e4b1f634ef049d]||||||


##Don’t leave Barcelona without trying…
*Vermut.* Sure, you’re familiar with the dry vermouth (in Catalan: *vermut*) of the classic martini cocktail, but did you know that in many European countries, it's served as a standalone libation? Vermut is a fortified, aromatic wine with a bitter aftertaste usually produced in three varieties: red, white, and rosé. Catalan vermut has notes of herbs and spices (think rosemary and orange—in fact, each producer uses its own secret concoction); and although its reputation there is as the drink of choice for Catalan grandfather-types, vermut is making a comeback among the young and trendy in Barcelona.

##Where to drink it
Traditionally, vermut is served in *bodegues* (Catalan *tavernas*) where it’s stored in wooden barrels, though ever since the recent vermut renaissance, it’s easy to find it in most cocktail bars as well. Vermut is normally served chilled with one or two ice cubes and garnished with an anchovy-stuffed olive. Some prefer it chilled without ice and garnished with an orange slice (red vermut) or a lemon slice (white vermut). Some even prefer to dilute it with soda water, so don’t be surprised if the waiter serves your vermut along with an old-fashioned soda siphon.

##When to drink it
Catalans drink vermut all year long, usually as an aperitif before lunch, but also in the late afternoon or even evening.

##How to order
Say: “*Em poses un vermut, si us plau?*” (Catalan for “Could you serve me a vermouth, please?”). The waiter or bartender should answer: “*Blanc, negre, o rosat?*” (White, red, or rosé?).

##How to pay
Normally you’ll pay when you are ready to leave. You can leave a small tip. Most bar-goers simply round up to the nearest euro and leave the change at the table.

##Local tip
Though it is now available in many cocktail bars, stick with the bodegues to enjoy the vermut on tap. Save the bottled vermut for drinking at home. If you do want to purchase a bottle in Barcelona, try to find something from local producers like Yzaguirre, Espinaler, or Miró. 

##Etiquette tips
__Don’t__ order a vermut late at night. This really is an aperitif and you’d most certainly be the recipient of strange looks.

__Do__ enjoy your vermut on an outdoor terrace with some [anchovies, olives, and almonds](http://www.contexttravel.com/city/barcelona/walking-tour-details/pica-pica-in-poble-sec-tapas-walk).

fields.name: Sara McCarty, Context Travel
fields.shortBio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel.
fields.bio: Sara McCarty is the France & Spain Manager at Context Travel. Context is a network of scholars and specialists—in disciplines including archaeology, art history, cuisine, urban planning, history, environmental science, and classics—who, in addition to our normal work as professors and researchers, design and lead in-depth walking seminars for small groups of intellectually curious travelers. The Context vision is to bring together  local scholars and specialists with curious travelers to educate and impassion them; to allow them access to places and cultures that might otherwise remain out of site to the casual visitor; to invite them off the tourist track and into the real life of the people, history, and culture that makes these cities, destinations.
